justification: "Our main outcome variable, perceived importance of change, was assessed using 6 items for each of the three behaviors… We aggregated across the items to create a mean importance-of-change composite for each behavior domain."

"In previous research that measured perceived importance of change … it has typically been measured using a single item akin to ‘How important is it for you to change your behavior?’ from 1 (not at all important) to 10 (extremely important)."

"In research involving either the transtheoretical-model or motivated-interviewing perspectives, readiness to change—measured as a continuous factor—has predicted both intentions and actual behavior change."

measured_by: Direct global comparison question (-3 to +3 scale recoded 1–7)
justification: "Direct global comparison questions asked ‘Think about an average person your age and gender. How much sleep do you typically get compared to the average person?’ … The three direct comparison questions were answered on scales ranging from ‑3 … to +3 … which were scored 1–7."
construct: Global comparison belief (self vs. average person)

measured_by: Direct local comparison question (-3 to +3 scale recoded 1–7)
justification: "Direct local comparison questions asked ‘Think about your close peers (people you see or hang out with often). How much sleep do you typically get compared to your close peers?’ … responses used the same ‑3 to +3 scale."
construct: Local comparison belief (self vs. close peer)

measured_by: Direct expert comparison question (-3 to +3 scale recoded 1–7)
justification: "Direct expert questions … asked ‘Think about the amount of sleep that experts recommend. How much sleep do you typically get compared to what experts recommend?’ … answered on the ‑3 to +3 scale that was scored 1–7."
construct: Expert comparison belief (self vs. expert recommendation)
